comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Open to correction by tramway experts - I think this is definitely Pitt Street looking south from about the Spring St corner. According to wikipedia, "Trams operated from Central station down Castlereagh Street to Circular Quay and back up Pitt Street in a large anti-clockwise loop.". Hence the single tramway line towards the left of the street. Not so sure about the "1900-1912" date. The City of Sydney website says that style of street light happened after 1912 - history.cityofsydney.nsw.gov.au/sydneystreets/Minding_the... Also the car ...

comment._content:

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Melbourne Steamship Co. Ltd, opened their Sydney office in 1905 - gallery.its.unimelb.edu.au/imu/imu.php?request=display&am...

comment.author: 18246605@N00
comment._content: Nice John. interesting to see that the car, probably a post WW1 unit by the look of it, is outnumbered by horse+cart. I'm leaning towards George Street but unsure.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/martindemo] It's already been proved it's Pitt Street. Check out the previous comments and notes on the photo, including the Google Street View link. And yes the predominance of horse and cart is fascinating.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Here we go - The new AMP Building with hoardings at ground level at 87 Pitt Street (see note) looks as if it is nearly complete and just about to open. The new building was opened on 21/1/1913 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/15392382 - which dates this photo to late 1912-1913. Another view of the new AMP building including one of those curly lamps - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=413625

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content:
Two earlier views, showing the demolished building -
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/5495542878/][http://www.flickr.com/photos/hwmobs/6918110708/]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Those photos show the earlier AMP Building well - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=63559. It strikes me that the new building (monstrosity) must have absorbed a couple of old laneways (?!) near Little George Street?? And I think it expanded again around 1918. Perplexed by the paucity of Pitt Street trams ... who pinched them?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: APOLOGIES! - The photographer is half-a-block NORTH of Spring Street intersection, outside the Wunderlich offices. See also the Melbourne Steamship office poster in this slightly earlier photo (from the different street lamps) - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2713167014/]mega zoomable - from.ph/29638 Revised GoogleMapsStreetView

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/martindemo] These discussions are why we love checking Flickr everyday! Fantastic! 
So the photographer was between Spring and Bridge Streets, possibly near Abercrombie Lane, looking south toward Central?

Regarding the date, my instincts said 1912, mainly due to the women's fashion. But the dates you all have provided are more reliable, thank you.

It is kind of depressing when you compare Google Street view with old Sydney, ha! Used to be so much better looking. Don't you just wish we still had the trams? :)
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: Agreed, Sydney during the "sandstone" era must have been a wonderful city to look at. Being born at the end of WW2 I recall the first curtain wall buildings and the demise of the city my grandparents and parents knew. The demise of the tramway system over the decade and a half after 1945/6 was as a result of one of the great planning follies of modern Australian government. Now thankfully redressed, but what a foundation for an effective transport system we trashed.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] An even better photo of the old AMP building, showing the lane beside -
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2533263654/]
I think your link shows an even earlier building - which suggests the one just completed above was the 3rd AMP building on the site.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] You are right, that is a much better picture of the 1878 AMP building at 87 Pitt Street (cnr Bond St). The AMP building I mistakenly linked to above was on the other side of Pitt Street, about where this photo was taken from, and earlier. See another A&APC image - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=63545 Confusing! They keep rebuilding Sydney every 30 years for the last 225 years!

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: I suspect the building site on the rhs might have become the 'new' New Zealand Insurance building which was located at 79-81 Pitt St. From what I've managed to scrape together via the digitised newspapers, the external building work appears to have been completed in ca. December 1912...and various notices indicate that the NZ Insurance Office moved into their new premises by about February 1913. It's a pity that there are large gaps in the digitised Sydney Mail (on Google News Archive) in the years 1912-1913...and of course the Australian Town & Country Journal (on Trove) hasn't yet been digitised beyond 1907...a couple of country newspapers carried this item on the recently completed building in February 1913...which suggests that the report might have been lifted from either the Sydney Mail or the T&CJ nla.gov.au/nla.news-article99613904 ; The NZI building was evidently a fairly substantial structure...140ft or so in height if this article is referring to the same building (see mid way down para titled 'Effect of the Act') nla.gov.au/nla.news-article15381970 ; so if the hole in the ground we see here was in fact the site of the later NZI building, then maybe we're looking at ca. early-mid 1912...but that doesn't stack up with BC's dates re the opening of the 'new' AMP building...unless the completion of the interior of the AMP building took up most of 1912... nla.gov.au/nla.news-article15271505 the miscellaneous notice near the bottom of the rhs column suggests that the demolition of the earlier building located at 79-81 Pitt St might have been underway in September 1911... Hey! Per his ADB entry adb.anu.edu.au/biography/spain-alfred-8594 , Col. Spain www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons/8390574071/ had a hand in the design of the NZI building!

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Hmm, it is confusing, I had this photograph to be taken near Abercrombie Lane looking toward Central based on this Powerhouse Museum photo beachcomber posted. Your suggested location seems like a completely different spot... P.S. just saw your edit to the post re Col Spain. He keeps popping up!
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] I've got the photographer standing on the footpath somewhere near Wunderlich Ltd's showrooms (which look to have been at 54 Pitt St)...looking south, towards the Empire Hotel (?101-103 Pitt St), which was on the corner of Pitt & Hunter Sts. From the numbering 79-81, I gather the NZI building would have occupied part of the block between Abercrombie Lane and Bond St...if the numbering hasn't been changed over the years, I'd say it might even have had a corner on Abercrombie Lane...the AMP building, 87 Pitt St (cnr of Bond), was then the first building in the next block... I managed to find a Kerry & Co page sized photo of the 'New Offices of the New Zealand Insurance Company Limited, Pitt-street, Sydney' in the Australian Town & Country Journal, 21 May, 1913 (p. 38)...but the accompanying item is essentially an advertisement for NZI, and it tells us very little about the building...it evidently had an 80 ft frontage to Pitt St...it was made of stone and brick...and reached to 9 stories above the street...plus had a basement...it had 2 lifts...no info whatsoever re when it was built, who the architects and builders were, or how much it cost. As it appears in the T&CJ, Kerry & Co's pic shows about a metre of the adjoining building (!)...I'm not 100% sure, but it appears to match up with the building we see here which has one wall exposed to the building site...alas the photocopy from the microfilm viewer was a bit of a dog...[http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02/8641575331/in/photostream]...there has to be a decent pic of the NZI building lying around somewhere...it looks to have been a bit of a mulligatawny...an Acropolis reject... This item is my source re the street number...it wasn't mentioned in the T&CJ item trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/99613904 acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=53176 I gather we see the NZI building here...in the block north of the AMP building...

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: nla.gov.au/nla.news-article15256660 ; nla.gov.au/nla.news-article28137847 background on the NZI building...the second item indicates that it was built above the course of the former Tank Stream...the foundations were evidently at an average depth of 29 ft beneath the level of Pitt St ...so it looks like demolition of the previous building at 79-81 Pitt St might have taken place in the 2nd half of 1911...if this is correct, then I'd say this pic might have been taken in the period ca. September 1911 - thru to ca. June 1912...if it were taken much earlier we'd see the previous building, either still standing or being demolished...and any later, we'd see the above ground level work on the NZI building in progress...just from what we see in this pic , I'd say the below ground or lower levels of the NZI building are under construction...so maybe we're looking at early 1912.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Wow, a lot of detail there! :) Thanks so much for your thorough research quasymody.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons
